awd_titl_txt: IRES:  Interdisciplinary student research on urban resilience in Latin America
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract: People living in cities in all regions of the world are experiencing increases in extreme events like floods and heat waves. Urban decision makers need help to develop ways to meet this challenge that are based in scientific understanding. This International Research Experience for Students (IRES) grant is linked to the Urban Resilience to Extremes (UREx) Sustainability Research Network (SRN). The grant will support three graduate students and one undergraduate student each year for ten weeks work in Valdivia, Chile (2017); Hermosillo, Mexico (2018); and in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic (2019). A total of nine UREx IRES graduate students will be trained over three years, broadening their skills in collaboration, transdisciplinary research methods, and in mentoring. They will gain appreciation for the unique challenges of Latin American cities, while benefiting from the opportunity to participate in research that is directly used by decision makers, and receive training and experience in workshop facilitation with local decision-makers and communities. Three UREx IRES undergraduate students will also gain research experience in a foreign country, learn about the process of science through not only conducting their own research project but working closely with graduate students conducting research, and gain skills in research design, data analysis and management, and presentation. This experience will help all of these students learn to work across diverse social and political cultures so that they might be more effective. The students who participate in this program will share their experiences with others in the UREx program through a reading group, blogs, and social media and at a capstone symposium to be organized in 2020 by UREx fellows.


Technical description: Cities are highly vulnerable to extreme, weather-related events, given their location along coastlines and in drylands. As urbanization continues as the main demographic trend worldwide, an ever-greater proportion of the population is exposed to hazard. Little research has been done on Latin American cities, where strategies to enhance their resilience in the face of such events may differ from US cities owing to cultural, political, or biophysical differences. The UREx SRN is a multi-city network of scientists and local practitioners, including Latin American cities, which studies, envisions, and develops innovative solutions to the challenges of these extreme events. Linked to the UREx SRN, the UREx IRES program will train students in working across cultures and disciplines and with local decision-makers. Mentors at the host institutions are collaborators in the UREx SRN and are conducting urban resilience research in these cities. The UREx IRES will afford opportunities for nine UREx fellows to expand their dissertation research into these Latin American cities, enabling projects that can be used to compare resilient solutions between US and Latin American cities. Three UREx IRES undergraduates will be selected to work on research projects in close collaboration with the graduate students, supervised by host mentors. The students' creativity is emphasized: as part of the UREx SRN they will have had experience with interdisciplinary research, training on Latin American cities, and will write a short research proposal that explains how their IRES project will integrate with their dissertation research and contribute to the overall knowledge-to-action efforts in the host city. UREx IRES fellows will be conducting transdisciplinary research with practitioners and host mentors that will advance basic scientific understanding of the characteristics of urban areas in general and infrastructure in particular that will lead to more resilient, and ultimately sustainable, cities in the future.

por.por_cntn:
RULA IRES - Project Outcomes Report

Cities are highly vulnerable to extreme, weather-related events and as urbanization continues, an ever-greater proportion of this population is exposed to hazards. In Latin American cities, strategies to enhance resilience in the face of such events may differ from US cities owing to cultural, political, or biophysical differences. By collaborating with a multi-city network of scientists and local practitioners (UREx SRN, NSF #1444755), we developed the Research in Urban Latin America International Research Experience for Students (RULA IRES) program to help students engage in transformative urban research. The project outcomes were motivated by an urgency to educate and train a new generation of students and professionals who can tackle climate change and urbanization as some of the greatest challenges of our time. The RULA IRES program trained graduate and undergraduate students to work across cultures and disciplines with local decision-makers. Mentors at the host institutions in Valdivia, Chile (2018), Hermosillo, Mexico (2019), and San Juan, Puerto Rico (2021) are collaborators in the UREx SRN and have been conducting urban resilience research. 

Intellectual Merit: 

 

To learn to work across diverse social and political cultures and to become effective change agents in the Anthropocene, we mentored over 20 students in affiliation with the RULA IRES program. Of those 20, this project has trained 12 students across three cohorts in the austral summer of 2018, and northern hemisphere summers of 2019 and 2021, in field methods, data synthesis and modeling, and survey instrument design and implementation. Students generated novel visualizations of their data and focused on co-producing or directly sharing their findings with local community leaders, non-profits, and decision makers in three Latin American cities. Fellows and participants in the RULA IRES program were evaluated to determine perceived differences in cultural settings, impact on the participant?s capacity to lead research projects, and the value of collaborating with graduate students from foreign institutions to better understand their cultural experience and to inform the development of cross-cultural multi-national projects and international research experience training programs. Notably, the triangulation of support for fellows among the host institutions, community organizations, and leadership team allowed for the development of deep cross-cultural exchange. 

 

Broader impacts: 

The research has contributed to four dissertations (one in progress), one Masters thesis, and two undergraduate honors theses. Four peer-reviewed journal publications, seven conference presentations, and a visual essay translated and delivered to the local communities in English and Spanish. In addition, social media and webinar outputs, like a featured episode in the Future Cities Podcast and presentations to the international audience of NATURA network of networks (NSF Accel-Net Award #1927167) webinar series, speak to the breadth of scholarly output formats. Fellows came from a broad range of disciplinary backgrounds including the arts, environmental science, urban planning, architecture, and environmental design. All fellows  conducted transdisciplinary research with practitioners and in-country host mentors that advanced basic scientific understanding of the characteristics of urban areas in general and infrastructure in particular that will lead to more resilient, and ultimately sustainable, cities in the future. NSF continues to provide support for this research through Nature Based Solutions RULA IRES Track 1 program NSF award #2107545  to offer international research experiences in Guayaquil, Ecuador (2023) and Merida, Mexico (slated for 2024). 



Figure 1. In Hermosillo, Mexico, fellows used mixed methods to estimate pluvial flood risk within the city. Red represents areas at risk of pluvial flooding according to a rational model for flooding developed by the city's main hydrology engineering firm, HEMEK. Blue represents pluvial flood risk which shows where water is likely to pool during extreme precipitation events. The green area was identified by locals as frequently experiencing pluvial flooding, which we captured through participatory mapping methods. This map combines the results of three different methods for estimating fluvial flood risk and gives us a more holistic understanding of areas that may be, or historically have been, at risk of pluvial flooding. We derive a better understanding of the mechanisms that create differences in the estimated locations of flooding by comparing these three methods.

 

Figure 2. In San Juan, Puerto Rico, fellows assessed how the historical development of the city could contribute to modern day flooding scenarios. The maps above depict the Urban Development of Portland Nuevo since 1941. Agricultural land and low-lying swamps (1941) were developed as one of the first suburban developments in San Juan (1949).



Figure 3. Students presented their findings at the San Juan ULTRA ?Transforming Cities? symposium, November 2021.
